channel.title: Comments on: How to efficiently stay on top of published research

item.title: By: Impact of Social Sciences – A number of freely available tools can help you improve your literature review routine and stay on top of published research
item.dc:creator: Impact of Social Sciences – A number of freely available tools can help you improve your literature review routine and stay on top of published research
item.description: […] edited version of the authors’ articles that originally appeared on the ScienceOpen and Green Tea and Velociraptors websites […]
item.content:encoded: […] edited version of the authors’ articles that originally appeared on the ScienceOpen and Green Tea and Velociraptors websites […]

item.title: By: Sylvain Ribault
item.dc:creator: Sylvain Ribault
item.description: In my field (theoretical physics) you just need to browse arXiv in the categories that are relevant to you. Publishing in journals is irrelevant to disseminating research. It is still done for one's career's sake, though.
item.content:encoded: In my field (theoretical physics) you just need to browse arXiv in the categories that are relevant to you. Publishing in journals is irrelevant to disseminating research. It is still done for one’s career’s sake, though.

item.title: By: Glendon Mellow
item.dc:creator: Glendon Mellow
item.description:
My personal favourite RSS reader is The Old Reader. https://theoldreader.com/
It mimics most of the features of Google Reader, and imports images and video really well. I maintain one for following blogs I'm personally interested in, and have used one for my social media management in healthcare work in the past. You can categorize blogs by custom topics and view all of them that way, or just read your whole stream.
item.content:encoded:
My personal favourite RSS reader is The Old Reader. https://theoldreader.com/

It mimics most of the features of Google Reader, and imports images and video really well. I maintain one for following blogs I’m personally interested in, and have used one for my social media management in healthcare work in the past. You can categorize blogs by custom topics and view all of them that way, or just read your whole stream.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/how-to-efficiently-stay-on-top-of-published-research/#comment-2431">Bianca Kramer</a>.
This is perfect, thanks, Bianca!
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Bianca Kramer.

This is perfect, thanks, Bianca!

item.title: By: Bianca Kramer
item.dc:creator: Bianca Kramer
item.description:
Here's an overview of what 20,000 people (75% researchers) use to get alerts/recommendations: http://dashboard101innovations.silk.co/page/Alerts
And in our database of 600+ research tools, we also have a list of available tools/platforms for this purpose: http://tinyurl.com/innoscholcomm-list-alerts
(hope inserting 2 links doesn't get me a one-way ticket on the spamtrain....)
item.content:encoded:
Here’s an overview of what 20,000 people (75% researchers) use to get alerts/recommendations: http://dashboard101innovations.silk.co/page/Alerts

And in our database of 600+ research tools, we also have a list of available tools/platforms for this purpose: http://tinyurl.com/innoscholcomm-list-alerts

(hope inserting 2 links doesn’t get me a one-way ticket on the spamtrain….)

item.title: By: Rintze Zelle
item.dc:creator: Rintze Zelle
item.description: I rely on weekly MyNCBI email updates for PubMed content (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/guide/howto/receive-search-results/), and manual biweekly checks of Lens.org for patent literature updates (unfortunately, Lens.org doesn't offer email alerts or RSS feeds, and is only updated every other week).
item.content:encoded: I rely on weekly MyNCBI email updates for PubMed content (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/guide/howto/receive-search-results/), and manual biweekly checks of Lens.org for patent literature updates (unfortunately, Lens.org doesn’t offer email alerts or RSS feeds, and is only updated every other week).

item.title: By: Dani
item.dc:creator: Dani
item.description:
You can follow #365papers and #230papers on twitter to see what other people are reading. Often people do round-up of a week or months reading so you can see what is relevant.
I've been finding a heap of papers through that!
item.content:encoded:
You can follow #365papers and #230papers on twitter to see what other people are reading. Often people do round-up of a week or months reading so you can see what is relevant.

I’ve been finding a heap of papers through that!
